bibl.title: Letter from Carl A. Grote to Henry Rose Carter, November 13, 1915

div1.p: Grote requests suggestions for a malaria eradication campaign. He notes that his county does not have the resources to purchase quinine.

div1.head: Letter from Carl A. Grote to Henry Rose Carter, November 13, 1915
div1.opener:
Copy.
Jasper, Alabama,
Nov. 13, 1915.
Mr. H. R. Carter,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I am writing to ask of you some suggestions
in reference to a compaign for the eradication of malaria in
Wlaker County. I am sure that you are familiar with conditions
and the geography of Walder County. We are now having a great
deal of malaria from Cordova, South. We had five deaths from
malaria reported for the month of October, and over this entire
section the disease seems to be widespread. Of course, I realize
that we cannot do very much this year, but I want to commence an
active compaign before another malarial season begins. The price
of quinine is now proving somewhat of an abstacel in the treatment
of our poorer people. I hope however, that this difficulty can
be overcome.

I spent one day with Dr. Griffith on his recent
visit to Cordova, and we found mosquitoes still breading. I
have not heard what his findings were in detail, but Dr. Tubbs
of Cordova, tells me that a great may Anophales Quadrimaculatus
hatched out from the larvae that we found. I am very sorry that
you were not able to pay us a second visit.

Of course, I donnot know what your plans are
for another year, but should the Public Health Service
decide to do any intensive work for the eradication of
malaria, I wish to extend a cordial invitation for them
to come to Walker County. I believe that we could secure
the cooperation necessary to make such a compaign a success.

Hoping that this is going to prove a very
pleasant winter for you, and with kindest personal regards,
I am
div1.closer:
Cordially yours, Carl A. Grote
COUNTY HEALTH OFFICER.
